title: Authors and Citation
Authors and Citation
text: Funk S (2023). epimixr: Epidemiological analysis using social mixing matrices. R package version 0.1.
code: @Manual{,   title = {epimixr: Epidemiological analysis using social mixing matrices},   author = {Sebastian Funk},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1}, }

what: Epidemiological analysis using social mixing matrices
title: Epidemiological analysis using social mixing matrices
text: epimixr R package uses social mixing matrices conduct epidemiological analysis. contains functions adjust_immunity (adjust population-level immunity mixing patterns described Funk et al., 2019), project_immunity (estimate immunity based vaccination data projecting forward given starting point age-specific susceptibility) epidemic_age_dist (estimate age distribution epidemic, see also finalsize package implements functionality perform task).

title: Epidemiological analysis using social mixing matrices
text: current development version can installed using remotes package

what: Estimate reproduction number from contact information and immunity profile — adjust_immunity
title: Estimate reproduction number from contact information and immunity profile — adjust_immunity
text: takes contact survey derive contact matrix rescales contacts represent contacts susceptibles. combined information basic reproduction number R0 calculate effective net reproduction number.

title: Estimate reproduction number from contact information and immunity profile — adjust_immunity
Estimate reproduction number from contact information and immunity profile — adjust_immunity
text: mixing_matrix mixing matrix, returned socialmixr::contact_matrix immunity immunity profile; given vector length number rows/columns mixing matrix; element vector contain value <1 representing proportion population immune corresponding age group; element set "herd" set 1-1/R0 vector TRUE, return eigenvector corresponding dominant eigenvector instead adjusted immunity; corresponds expected stable age distribution infections case outbreak

title: Estimate reproduction number from contact information and immunity profile — adjust_immunity
Estimate reproduction number from contact information and immunity profile — adjust_immunity
Estimate reproduction number from contact information and immunity profile — adjust_immunity
code: library("socialmixr") #>  #> Attaching package: ‘socialmixr’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:utils’: #>  #>     cite mixing <- contact_matrix(survey = polymod, age.limits   = c(0, 5, 10)) #> Using POLYMOD social contact data. To cite this in a publication, use the 'cite' function #> Removing participants without age information. To change this behaviour, set the 'missing.participant.age' option #> Removing participants that have contacts without age information. To change this behaviour, set the 'missing.contact.age' option adjust_immunity(mixing$matrix, immunity = c(0, 0.5, 0.8)) #> [1] 0.7069723

what: Calculates the age distribution of an epidemic — epidemic_age_dist
title: Calculates the age distribution of an epidemic — epidemic_age_dist
text: calculates age distribution epidemic setting using iterative method : J Wallinga, P Teunis, M Kretschmar (2006)  Using Data Social Contacts Estimate Age-specific Transmission Parameters Respiratory-spread Infectious Agents. J Epidemiol 164(10), 945-946.

title: Calculates the age distribution of an epidemic — epidemic_age_dist
code: epidemic_age_dist(   mixing_matrix,   r_0,   immunity = 0,   final_size_start = 0.01,   tol = 1e-05 )

title: Calculates the age distribution of an epidemic — epidemic_age_dist
text: mixing_matrix mixing matrix set mixing matrices, returned socialmixr::contact_matrix r_0 basic reproduction number immunity proportion immune epidemic final_size_start starting value inidence tol tolerance stopping iteration

title: Calculates the age distribution of an epidemic — epidemic_age_dist
text: matrix final size(s) (proportion susceptibles infected)   age group (one row per matrix contained mixing)

title: Calculates the age distribution of an epidemic — epidemic_age_dist
code: library("socialmixr") mixing <- contact_matrix(survey = polymod, age.limits = c(0, 5, 10)) #> Using POLYMOD social contact data. To cite this in a publication, use the 'cite' function #> Removing participants without age information. To change this behaviour, set the 'missing.participant.age' option #> Removing participants that have contacts without age information. To change this behaviour, set the 'missing.contact.age' option epidemic_age_dist(mixing$matrix, r_0 = 5, immunity = 0.50) #>        [0,5)    [5,10)      10+ #> [1,] 0.18991 0.4972204 0.959609

what: Project immunity from a baseline — project_immunity
title: Project immunity from a baseline — project_immunity
text: Project immunity baseline via vaccination coverage rates

title: Project immunity from a baseline — project_immunity
code: project_immunity(   baseline_immunity,   baseline_year,   year,   coverage,   schedule,   maternal_immunity,   efficacy )

title: Project immunity from a baseline — project_immunity
text: baseline_immunity baseline immunity, named vector; names correspond lower limits age groups, vector corresponding levels immunity. baseline_year year baseline immunity taken (corresponding column coverage argument) year year project coverage coverage multiple vaccine doses, given matrix row dose (named) column year schedule ages vaccines given (years). maternal_immunity proportion maternally immune. efficacy vaccine efficacy.

title: Project immunity from a baseline — project_immunity
text: data frame immunity levels age group ( baseline_immunity).

title: Project immunity from a baseline — project_immunity
Project immunity from a baseline — project_immunity
code: baseline_immunity <- c(`2` = 0.85, `5` = 0.9, `10` = 0.95) coverage <- matrix(rep(0.9, 10), nrow = 2) colnames(coverage) <- as.character(seq(2015, 2019)) project_immunity(   baseline_immunity, 2018, 2019, coverage = coverage,   schedule = c(1, 2), 0.5, 0.95 ) #>         0         2         5        10  #> 0.6775000 0.8929917 0.8900000 0.9500000
